text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with creole crab and corn chowder
that's right Mardi Gras is just around
the corner so I thought to help
celebrate why don't I do some kind of
New Orleans inspired soup of course I
have no idea if they need anything like
this in New Orleans but it does use
ingredients they seem to enjoy corn crab
and this the old Holy Trinity onions
peppers and celery and by the way I'm
using all jalapeno but you can use any
combination of mild or hot green peppers
alright so we're going to dump the old
Holy Trinity of aromatic vegetables into
our pot with some melted butter I'm also
going to add a nice pinch of salt and
we're going to sweat that over medium
heat for about 6-7 minutes until the
vegetables kind of soften and the onions
start to turn translucent now if you
like a little sweeter profile you could
go golden brown on these if you tend to
like things a little more savory
alright you probably want to stop right
here but as they say in New Orleans you
are the boss of your Trinity only they
say it in French and it sounds so much
cooler all right so once our vegetables
are done we're gonna spice it up a
little bit I'm going to add some old bay
and some cayenne pepper by the way as
I've warned you before please do not use
middle-aged bay alright once that's
mixed in I'm going to add a rounded
tablespoon of flour to form a little bit
of a roux and this is going to thicken
the chowder just a little bit extra it's
going to be pretty thick just from the
corn and the crab but this is going to
give it a little extra body and if
there's one thing they love in New
Orleans it's extra body alright so we've
cooked our flour for about two minutes
on medium at that point we're going to
stir in some cold water now water does
work but if you happen to have some fish
stock or shellfish stock vegetable broth
even chicken broth you could also use
that for a little extra flavor but you
probably already knew that
all right we're also going to add half
our corn nut kernels what about the
other half
whoo stay tuned you're gonna see of
course if you can swing it use fresh
sweet summer corn freshly shucked if not
and you're in the middle of winter like
we are use a really nice organic frozen
sweet corn
it'll be fine trust me all right and
then two ounces of the crab which is
going to be about a quarter of our crab
I like to cook a little bit into the
soup at this point I think it gives it a
little bit of a stronger flavor but I do
like to put most of it in fresh at the
end all right so the corns in the crab
is in alright we're going to raise the
heat up to medium-high and we're going
to bring this up to a simmer now while
we're waiting we're going to put the
other half of the corn in a blender with
a little bit of water and some garlic
and that was only a couple cloves of
garlic it looked like a lock as they you
know kind of broke when I crushed them
we're going to puree that mixture and
we're going to go ahead and pour that
into the soup pots so we'll stir that in
and we're going to wait for this to come
up to a simmer so we're going to keep an
eye on it
when you see it start to simmer you're
going to go ahead and give it a stir
back the heat down to low and let this
simmer for about 3540 minutes
all right just down low it's going to
reduce a little bit the color is going
to deepen a little bit it's going to
definitely thicken up and it will look
something like that all right
so we're ready to finish this off and
we're going to do that with a big spoon
of sweet paprika not smoked not spicy
just regular high-quality Spanish
paprika a nice big splash of cream and
the rest of our fresh crab that's
another six ounces so I had a half a
pound total as you saw we put in two
ounces at the beginning so we're going
to stir all that in and we're getting
close to being done and regarding the
paprika not only is that going to give
some flavor but corn chowder is not the
most beautiful soup in the world has
that kind of pale yellow color so I kind
of like what the paprika does to the
color kind of gives it a little bit of
an orange blush and as soon as that crab
is heated through and you've tasted and
adjusted the seasoning you are ready to
eat your Creole crab and corn chowder
ladle this up into a bowl top with some
fancy cut green onions I could have just
sliced them but I wanted to assert my
culinary dominance a little pinch of
cayenne just to stay in shape and there
you go
oh by the way speaking of Mardi Gras you
would not believe what I had to do to
get those beads and yes it looks very
rustic and rustic is what we chefs call
things that are you know kind of ugly
but really super delicious and it really
is that sweet crab that sweet corn the
aromatic vegetables the spice from the
Cayenne in the old bay
just a really really nice chowder and
certainly something that would hit the
spot on a chilly winter night and like I
said if it's the middle of summer of
course use the fresh corn anyway I hope
you give that a try
all the ingredients are on food wishes
comm along with more information as
usual and as always enjoy
